citation.article-title: Limnobacter thiooxidans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel thiosulfate-oxidizing bacterium isolated from freshwater lake sediment.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Limnobacter thiooxidans sp. nov.
Limnobacter thiooxidans (thi.o.ox'i.dans. Gr. n. thion sulfur;M.L. v. oxido to make acid, oxidize;M.L. part. adj. thiooxidans oxidizing sulfur)
Cells are slightly curved rods with pointed ends, 1.5-3.7 μm long with a diameter of 0.6-1.5 μm.
They occur singly or in short chains and are motile by single polar flagella.
Elemental sulfur is not deposited intra- or extracellularly during growth on media containing thiosulfate.
Colonies on R2A medium reach a diameter of 0.8-1.0 mm and are circular, smooth, translucent and flat with entire margins.
Aggregates are formed during growth in liquid culture.
The pH range for growth is pH 5.5-10.5.
Yeast extract and vitamins are not required for growth.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite by strain CS-K2T.
Several carboxylic acids and amino acids are used as sources of carbon and energy.
The following compounds were identified as substrates for growth by the Biotype 100 system: fumarate, succinate, L-malate, L-aspartate and L-glutamate.
In the presence of an organic substrate, thiosulfate can be used as an energy source, enabling chemolithoheterotrophic growth.
The G+­C content of the DNA is 55 mol% (Tm).
Isolated from the littoral sediment of a freshwater lake.
The type strain is strain CS-K2T (=DSM13612T=LMG 19593T).
